interpretation_summary: The preregistered replication executed successfully after several rounds of debugging path-handling and cluster-SE issues.  The final Python script reproduced the intended ordinary-least-squares model with village–clustered standard errors for three specifications (full sample, alternative outcome, and UP/Bihar subset).  All three replicated coefficients on the key treatment (low-caste-dominated village) are small, negative and statistically insignificant, whereas the original study reported a large positive and highly significant effect.  Methodological fidelity is high with respect to the preregistration, but two substantive deviations from the original design remain: (i) the main analysis uses a broader 17-state LSMS sample (although a UP/Bihar subset was run as a robustness check) and (ii) instrumental-variables estimation used in the original paper was not replicated.  Overall, the replication does not support the original claim under any tested specification.

fidelity_assessment.method_alignment: Substantive alignment with the preregistration: OLS regressions of agricultural income per cultivated acre on an indicator for BAC-dominated village, household controls, and state×caste fixed effects; village-clustered SEs exactly as planned.  The code changes were purely technical (wrapper script, file-path resolution, explicit list-wise deletion) and did not alter the underlying estimation.

deviations.issue_description: Replication used an extended 17-state LSMS sample rather than restricting to Uttar-Pradesh & Bihar as in the original article.
deviations.impact: Medium: Different geographic mix may attenuate or reverse the treatment effect; the UP/Bihar subset also yielded null results, but the sample shrank considerably (N≈500).

deviations.issue_description: No instrumental-variables specification was estimated, whereas the original paper emphasised IV to address irrigation endogeneity.
deviations.impact: Medium: If endogeneity is severe, OLS may bias estimates toward zero, potentially explaining the null finding.

results_comparison.hypothesis_tested: Among low-caste households, residing in a village dominated by lower castes (locaste_land_v = 1) is associated with higher agricultural income per cultivated acre than residing in an upper-caste dominated village.
results_comparison.original_results: OLS coefficient for ‘Low-caste village’ = 566.5 (SE = 209), p < 0.01; positive and economically large effect on agricultural income.
results_comparison.replication_results: Full-sample raw income: β = -10.0 (SE = 10.6), p = 0.344; Full-sample net income: β = -2.8 (SE = 7.23), p = 0.700; UP/Bihar subset raw income: β = -7.73 (SE = 10.81), p = 0.475.  All effects negative and not statistically significant.
results_comparison.overall_answer: No – the replication fails to meet the preregistered criterion of a positive, significant coefficient; results are null to slightly negative.

replication_report: Replication unsuccessful: In contrast to the original paper’s strong positive association (β≈566, p<0.01), the replicated coefficients are small, negative and not significant across all specifications, providing no evidence that low-caste dominance raises agricultural income per acre.

failure_handling.suggestions: Replicate the original instrumental-variables approach using the water-availability instruments to match causal identification; assess whether OLS attenuation drives the null result.

Re-create the exact UP & Bihar sample used in the original study and verify variable construction (e.g., total income vs. income per acre; inclusion of water-buyer interaction) to isolate sample-composition effects.

notes: Results may be sensitive to the definition of the dependent variable (per acre vs. total income) and to the exclusion of water-buyer interaction terms highlighted in the original causal mechanism.  A future robustness exercise could incorporate these components and perform a leave-one-state-out analysis to diagnose heterogeneity.
